'''John Jacob (J.J.) Malone''' (August 20, 1935 – February 20, 2004)<ref name="Dead" /> was an [[United States|American]] [[West Coast blues]], [[electric blues]] and [[soul blues]] guitarist, singer and keyboardist.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/jj-malone-mn0000777454/biography |title=J.J. Malone | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> His best known [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] were "It's a Shame" and "Danger Zone".  Malone was a member of The Rhythm Rockers, and variously worked with musicians such as Troyce Key, Jill Baxter, [[Al Green]], [[Joe Simon (musician)|Joe Simon]], [[Etta James]], [[Scott McKenzie]] and Frankie Lee.<ref name="Dead" /><ref name="Find" />

==Biography==
Malone was born in Pete's Corner, [[Alabama]], [[United States]]. He sang in his local church, and learned to play the harmonica, guitar and piano.<ref name="Encyc">{{cite book |author=Herzhaft, Gérard, et al. |year=1997 |title=Encyclopedia of the Blues |edition=1st |publisher=[[University of Arkansas Press]] |location=[[Fayetteville, Arkansas]] |isbn=1-55728-452-0 |page=127}}</ref> After moving to [[California]], he found more regular employment in the [[music industry]], and had localised [[hit single]]s with "It's a Shame", "One Step Away", and "Danger Zone". Malone met the [[record producer]], Ray Shanklin, and was subsequently employed as a record company executive at [[Fantasy Records]] (and it's subsidiary [[Galaxy Records|Galaxy]]) in the late 1960s and early 1970s. At Galaxy, Malone worked alongside [[Little Johnny Taylor]], [[Big Mama Thornton]], [[Sonny Rhodes]] and [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]]. With the singer and guitarist, Troyce Key, he bought a [[nightclub|club]] near to [[Oakland, California]], 'The Eli's Mile', which in the 1970s acquired a reputation for supporting West Coast blues artists.<ref name="Encyc" /> In 1980, the duo appeared at the [[San Francisco Blues Festival]].

Malone appeared in conjunction with Key on the albums, ''I've Gotta a New Car'' (1980, Red Lightnin' Records),<ref>{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/ive-gotta-new-car-mw0000839895 |title=I've Gotta New Car - Troyce Key | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> and ''Younger Than Yesterday'' (1981, Red Lightnin').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/younger-than-yesterday-mw0000811488/credits |title=Younger Than Yesterday - Troyce Key | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> Malone returned to performing as a solo artist in the 1980s, and continued to record until 2001.<ref name="Find"/> He released three solo albums, including ''Highway 99'' (1997).<ref name="Discography" />

Malone died from [[cancer]] in [[Hawaii]], in February 2004 at the age of 68. He was buried next to his father on March 2, 2004, at Ragland Cemetery in [[Limestone County, Alabama]].<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2004.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 2004 January To June |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref><ref name="Find">{{cite web |url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=8525901 |title=J.J. Malone |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Findagrave.com |accessdate=October 29, 2011}}</ref>
